awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation Award: Magnetic Field Mapping of Pico/Nano/Micro-Satellites to Facilitate Refinement of their Guidance/Navigation Systems and Magnetic Cleanliness
awd_abstract_narration:
Research Initiation Awards provide support for junior and mid-career faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities who are building new research programs or redirecting and rebuilding existing research programs. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improves research and teaching at his home institution, and involves undergraduate students in research experiences. The award to Tuskegee University has potential broader impact in a number of areas. The project seeks to investigate methods of mapping the electromagnetic field distribution of pico/nano/micro satellites (PNMSats) and aid in the refinement of their orbit determination and control capabilities. Undergraduate aerospace engineering students will gain research experiences by working on the project.  

The overall research goal is to develop a better understanding of the magnetic activity of PNMSats and investigate methods of modeling the magnetic map of such satellites.  A Magnet Coil Test Facility, designed around a 3-axes Helmholtz coil (HHC) cage and precision fluxgate magnetometers, will be used for carrying out the research.  The PNMSat specimens will be subject to relevant on-orbit control modes inside the HHC cage. Using the magnetometer measurements taken during the emulation of these control modes, a harmonic understanding of the magnetic activity will be investigated.  The research will aid in the refinement of the various subsystems of a PNMSat - particularly the operation of attitude determination and control systems, as well as electro-magnetically sensitive instrumentation. It will further aid in designing magnetic booms for PNMSats.  This research is a stepping stone to founding a PNMSat program at Tuskegee University and provides an opportunity for collaboration with other Historically Black Colleges and Universities.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Compactly designed satellites hosting magnetic or electric motor based actuators have a continuously changing magnetic field distribution, which can adversely affect the sensor/instrument measurements captured for attitude/orbit computations or science data collection. A significant outcome of this project is a 2-step process for mapping the magnetic field of such a compactly designed satellite. The 2-step process involves, (i) carrying out experiments in a Helmholtz cage (HHC) to obtain discrete measurements of the satellite magnetic field, and (ii) performing a Fourier analysis to extrapolate the discrete measurements into a continuous map. The magnetic maps, thus developed, facilitate an understanding of the adverse effects of satellite magnetic field on sensors, instruments. In the larger context of the development of the principal discipline of the project, one can think of this approach as a means of understanding the magnetic field of any entity, including those of planetary bodies. The magnetic maps developed using the 2-step process could assist in determining the magnetic field distribution of planetary bodies as well.

The Earth's magnetic field is a significant factor, which affects seed germination and plant growth. However, this factor varies considerably in space and on the surface of planetary bodies, including Moon and Mars. The research has demonstrated that magnetic field exposure (MFE) of plants may result in changes in their physiology, growth, performance, chemical structures, etc. Through this study, we developed a detailed protocol and through macro-analysis, we observed an increased biomass, among others, in selected plant species due to an uncharacteristic MFE, representative of non Earth-like MFE. As we explore the frontiers of outer space and look to Moon, Mars, and exoplanets as future home, it is critical to investigate plant responses to super-weak magnetic fields (Moon’s magnetic field is <0.01 that of Earth) in non Earth-like environments. A follow-up study could be critical in quantifying the effects of MFE on plant germination, physiology, growth, and the nutrients through microanalysis such as nuclear magnetic resonance - NMR - analyses of their chemical structure. The investigation could address several outcomes, including relevance to Earth-based agriculture, insight gained on plant physiology, cellular processes, performance, and inspiration for research/outreach on Earth.

Chlorella vulgaris is a commonly found eukaryotic green microalgae species that frequently appears in many natural and manmade freshwater and soil environments. It is known to be a source for biofuels and has the ability to decrease the amount of greenhouse gasses in the atmosphere. Chlorella vulgaris is extremely dense (60-66%) in protein and is increasingly being explored for human consumption. Chlorella based microorganisms, which have existed for thousands of years through evolution, exhibit unique structural features, which enables them to be considerably superior and cost-effective for micro/nanofabrication techniques. The environmental impact like that of the outer space experienced on the International Space Station or orbits around planetary bodies can have a critical impact on the overall growth and production of bioactive compounds of Chlorella vulgaris. This research has demonstrated that treatment of Chlorella vulgaris with increased MFE can have a significant impact on its overall growth and bioactive compounds production. 

Overall, the Mission SeaLion CubeSat desing and development has been a major activtiy of this project and engaged ~50 undergraduate students, ~10 graduate students, and faculty. The project has provided an opportunity for the students and faculty of ODU to work directly with a former U.S. NASA astronaut CAPT Daniel Burbank, USCG (Retired). The students have worked with colleagues in the Batten College of Engineering and Technology (BCET) and Collge of Sciences at ODU, with partners in the U.S. Coast Guard Academy,  and a visiting researcher from The Center for Research and Assistance in Technology and Design of the State of Jalisco, AC (CIATEJ), Guadalajara, Jalisco (Mexico). All the students engaged in the project received significant training in Space Systems Engineering, Space Biology, and in the prepration of scholarly articles. Several of them have produced (or in the process of producing) scholarly outcomes in the form of conference presentations, conference proceedings article, M.S. Thesis, journal articles, scholarship symposium articles/presentations, etc.

One of the ODU students who was mentored by the PI since he was a sophomore is currently admitted into the accelerated B.S./M.S. program in Aerospace Engineering at ODU. He is the recepient of two significant scholarships from Virginia AeroSpace Business Association and the Virginia Space Grant Consortium (VSGC). Several ODU students have pursued their Masters in Aerospace Engineering at ODU and defended their M.S. Thesis in this project. The PI mentored two African-American female undergraduate students as part of this project. One student received ODU’s Batten College of Engineering (BCET) Diversity Scholarship to pursue her Ph.D., and the other student received the RISE scholarship at ODU to pursue her Ph.D. in BCET. One of these students also received a significant scholarship from the VSGC after she joined her M.S./Ph.D. program at ODU.

 

 


Last Modified: 04/15/2024
Modified by: Sharana Basawes Asundi
